Award.AbstractNarration:
Historically statistics has dealt with extracting as much information as possible from a small data set. However, much of modern statistical research focusses on data sets that have enormous numbers of predictors. This phenomenon is a direct result of recent technological advances that have affected various fields of research, such as image processing, computational biology, and finance. This proposal addresses a very important question of fitting nonlinear regression models in high-dimensional situations, where the number predictors may be much larger than the number of observations. Unlike linear or generalized linear models, high-dimensional nonlinear regression is a very young research area that requires systematic and extensive development. Due to the curse of dimensionality, most of the work in this area has been conducted under the assumption that the regression function has a simple additive structure. The investigator proposes novel methodology for fitting index type regression models in high dimensions. The new methods cover models that are either complimentary or strictly more general than the additive models studied before. For each of the methods the proposal presents a computationally efficient fitting algorithm and lays out a plan for establishing theoretical results.

The proposed research is expected to have a broad impact on the practice and education of statistics and related fields. Disciplines such as Computational Biology, Finance, Marketing and Machine Learning are highly interested in the type of methodology that is targeted in this proposal. The investigator plans to systematically develop software for implementing the proposed methods through free software packages and then make them readily available to researchers in the aforementioned fields. The proposed research will also have an impact on the growth and development of the new USC Statistics Ph.D. program. Several students in this young program will be involved in methodology research, algorithm development, and theoretical investigation. They will get hands on experience and guidance in the very important field of high-dimensional statistical inference.

Historically, statistics has dealt with extracting as much information as possible from a small data set. However, much of modern statistical research focusses on data sets that have enormous numbers of predictors.  This phenomenon is a direct result of recent technological advances that have affected various areas of research.  Fields ranging from finance, marketing and economics to image analysis, signal processing, data compression and computational biology nowadays share the common feature of trying to extract information from vast noisy data sets.    Recent developments in mobile computing and social media have also produced an unimaginably vast amount of digital information.  Meanwhile, the age of Big Data has created an abundance of interesting problems, posing new challenges, not present in conventional data analysis.  Such large scale problems fall under the general framework of high-dimensional statistical inference, which was the area of study in the research project conducted by the investigator.  The main focus of the project was placed on developing successful new approaches in the areas of of high-dimensional nonlinear regression and functional data analysis.

The work on high dimensional regression problems involves fitting models and performing variable selection in settings where the number of predictors, p, is large relativeto the number of observations.  In such situations classical approaches will generally fail, because they are not computationally feasible for large p.  There has been a great deal of recent research on this important topic, because of the increasing occurrence of data sets with enormous numbers of predictors. Some important examples include gene expression studies, where there are many genes and few observations, large panel longitudinal data in economics and finance, signal processing, and functional magnetic resonance imaging and tomography.   The investigator developed a new approach for fitting high-dimensional single index models.  These models generalize linear regression by replacing the linear predictor with a nonparametric component. Due to their flexibility and interpretability, single index models are becoming increasingly popular in many scientific fields including financial econometrics, economics and biostatistics.  Very limited research, however, had been conducted on extending these models to the high-dimensional setting.  The novel methodology developed by the investigator makes an important contribution to statistics and related scientific fields.

The key principle of the functional data analysis field is to treat the measurements of a function or curve not as multiple data points, but as a single observation of the function as a whole.  This approach allows one to more fully exploit the structure of the data. Functional data analysis  is an inherently multi-disciplinary area and is becoming increasingly important as we continue to collect larger and larger data sets.  The investigator, together with his collaborators, developed several new approaches for dealing with sparsely observed predictors, as well as high-dimensional problems involving a large number of functional predictors.  The novel methodology extends beyond the standard linear regression setting to fit general nonlinear additive models.
